questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the skeletal muscle contraction?

choices.text: Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
Extracellular Ca2+ is not important for contraction
Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on sarcolemma have no role in excitation-contraction coupling

questions.solution:
During the contraction of the skeletal muscle, the Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Option B is correct.

Excitation-contraction coupling refers to the process by which the membrane depolarization of the muscle fiber (excitation) leads to the contraction of the muscle.

The steps of excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle are as follows:

  • Motor-neuron discharge causes the release of acetylcholine at the motor endplate, which binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.
  • This causes increased Na+ and K+ conductance in the endplate membrane, leading to the generation of end-plate potential, which is a local potential.
  • When the local endplate potential reaches a threshold for the muscle fiber, an action potential is generated.
  • The generated action potential passes inward through the T tubules, leading to the spread of depolarisation.
  • The depolarization of the muscle fiber causes the release of Ca2+ from terminal cisterns of the sarcoplasmic reticulum and diffusion to thick and thin filaments.
  • The calcium released, binds to troponin C, uncovering myosin-binding sites on actin.
  • The formation of cross-linkages between actin and myosin and sliding of thin on thick filaments causes contraction of the skeletal muscle.

Steps in relaxation:

  • The cytoplasmic calcium is pumped back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, by the action of SERCA (sarcoplasmic endoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase).
  • Once the calcium concentration is lowered, the interaction between actin and myosin ceases, and the muscle relaxes. 
Other options:
 
Option A: Incorrect - Ca2+ is not released from mitochondria. It is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
Option C: Incorrect - Extracellular calcium levels play an important role in muscle contraction. When there is a decrease in extracellular calcium as in hypocalcemia, the voltage-gated sodium channels are activated, which causes sodium influx. The increased intracellular sodium concentration causes sustained depolarization, which may lead to tetany.
Option D: Incorrect - Voltage-gated calcium channels on the sarcoplasmic reticulum are activated by a depolarizing stimulus, which causes the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. The increased calcium concentration will eventually lead to muscle contraction.

questions.text:
Match the following sodium channels to their sites of reabsorption in the nephron:
Site Transport channel
1. Early proximal convoluted tubule A. Na+–2Cl-–K+ cotransporter
2. Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle B. Epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs)
3. Distal convoluted tubule C. Sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT) 
4. Collecting duct D. Na+-Cl- cotransporter
questions.solution:
The correct option is Option C: 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B. 

Reabsorption of sodium in different parts of the nephron are:

  • Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT): 
    • Nearly 60% of the filtered sodium is reabsorbed in the PCT. Solutes mainly absorbed in the proximal tubule are sodium, chloride, bicarbonate, phosphate, lactate, glucose, amino acids etc. 
    • In early PCT, the main sodium channels used for reabsorption are Na+-glucose cotransporter (SGLT), Na+-H+ exchanger, Na+-amino acid cotransporter, Na+-phosphate cotransporter, etc. 
    • In distal PCT, due to high chloride concentration in the lumen, it favors NaCl reabsorption, driven by Cl− gradient. 
    • The total solute and water reabsorption are proportional to each other. Thus, the entire proximal tubule also reabsorbs nearly 60% of the filtered water (isosmotic reabsorption). 
  • Loop of Henle:
    • The thin descending limb has no active transport of Na+ outside the lumen but the loop is permeable to water, making the tubular fluid hypertonic.
    • A thick ascending limb reabsorbs nearly 30% of the Na+ by Na–2Cl–K cotransporter, an example of secondary active transport. This loop is impermeable to water. Since some of the solutes are reabsorbed and water is not reabsorbed, it dilutes the tubular fluid. Other ions like Ca 2+, and Mg2+ are also absorbed here. 
  • Distal convoluted tubule: Approximately 7% of the filtered load of sodium chloride is reabsorbed in the early distal tubule. This occurs due to the presence of sodium chloride co-transporter. Even this segment dilutes the tubular fluid as it is impermeable to water. 
  • Cortical collecting tubule: The remaining 3% of the filtered Na+ is absorbed via ENaCs (epithelial sodium channels) in this duct.  This portion is regulated by aldosterone to maintain homeostasis in Na+ balance.

Clinical aspect: 

i) Barrter syndrome is a congenital renal disorder due to mutation in Na–2Cl–K cotransporter, ROMK K+ channel, ClC–Kb Cl− channel, or barttin. It is characterized by chronic urinary Na+ loss, with hypovolemia, hypokalemia, and alkalosis.

ii) Gitelman syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting the sodium chloride co-transporter in the distal tubules, leading to decreased sodium chloride reabsorption. 

iii) Liddle syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder where mutation results in increased activity of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) in the distal and collecting tubules. This leads to increased reabsorption of sodium and water causing hypertension and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: The following process where transportation is along the concentration gradient is an example of:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a glucose transporter that transports glucose from a higher concentration to a lower concentration. This is an example of facilitated diffusion. 

When carrier proteins help in the movement of substances in the direction of their chemical or electrical gradients (downhill movement), no energy input is required and the process is called facilitated diffusion.

Glucose transporters also referred to as GLUTs, are transport proteins in the cell membrane responsible for the transfer of glucose into the cells by facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion involves the passage of molecules or ions inside the cell membrane by binding to a carrier/ transport protein. 

For example, insulin stimulates glucose entry into the cells via facilitated diffusion by increasing the number of glucose transporters (GLUTs) in the cell membrane. This type of insulin-dependent glucose transport via GLUT 4 is observed in skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissues. 

Other options - 

Option A. Simple diffusion - It is along the concentration gradient but is not carrier-mediated. In the cell, examples of molecules that can use simple diffusion to travel in and out of the cell membrane are water, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen. They pass directly through the cell membrane without energy along the concentration gradient.

Option C. Primary active transport - It is a form of cellular transport requiring energy in the form of hydrolysis of ATP to ship and transfer molecules against a membrane with chemical or electrical gradient differences. The important examples of primary active transport include sodium-potassium ATPase, proton pump, and calcium ATPase.

Option D. In secondary active transport, the active transport of sodium is coupled to the transport of other substances. Examples include symport of sodium with glucose (luminal membranes of mucosal cells in the small intestine), sodium-potassium ATPase, and Ca2+ in the cardiac muscle cells.

questions.text: In the following pressure-volume loop diagram of left ventricle, the mitral valve will close at the point:
questions.solution:
The closure of the mitral valve corresponds to point 2, which marks the beginning of the isovolumetric contraction phase.

 The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • Point 1 - Mitral valve opens
  • Point 2 - Mitral valve closes
  • Point 3 - Aortic valve opens
  • Point 4 - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling:  

  • In the given diagram, the period of filling lasts from point 1 to point 2.
  • At point A, the volume of blood present in the left ventricle is the end-systolic volume which corresponds to about 50 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve opens and the venous blood flows into the left ventricle from the left atrium.
  • At point B, the end of the period of filling—the amount of blood present in the left ventricle is called the end-diastolic volume which corresponds to about 120 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve closes.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction:

  • In the given diagram, the period of isovolumetric contraction lasts from point 2 to point 3.
  • At point B, the mitral valve closes and the volume of the ventricle does not change as all the valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle continues to rise.
  • At point C the ventricular pressure increases to become equal to the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) and then the aortic valve opens.

Phase III: Period of ejection

  • In the given diagram, the period of ejection lasts from point 3 to point 4.
  • At point C, the aortic valve opens and the volume of the ventricle decreases as the blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.
  • The systolic pressure continues to rise as the ventricle contracts.
  • At point D the aortic valve closes.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

  • In the given diagram, the period of relaxation lasts from point 4 to point 1.
  • At point D, the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. 
  • This decrease in intraventricular pressure occurs without any change in volume.
  • At point A, the ventricle now has an end-systolic volume of 50 ml of blood similar to the beginning of the cycle.

questions.text: A normal healthy adult participated in a respiratory study that was conducted to understand the respiratory functions. In the upright position, an increase in all of the following parameters can be seen with respect to the base of the lungs except?
questions.solution:
In the upright position, an increase in the ventilation-perfusion ratio (V/Q ratio) is not seen with respect to the base of the lungs. At the base of the lung, the V/Q ratio is decreased. 

V/Q ratio is the ratio of alveolar ventilation (V) to pulmonary blood flow (Q) for the lungs at rest. The average value of the V/Q ratio throughout the lungs is 0.8. When this ratio is mismatched, it can cause CO2 retention (when solely, ventilation is impaired) or lowered arterial O2 (when perfusion is impaired). 

Normally, in the upright position, the V/Q ratio in the normal lungs markedly undergoes changes from the apex to the base due to the effect of gravity as shown below - 

 

At the base of the lung:

Both ventilation and perfusion increase since the flow is towards gravity.

Increased ventilation is due to the increase in intrapleural pressure compared to the apex, thereby making the intrapulmonary intrapleural pressure difference less at the base. Thus, due to this low-pressure difference, the lung is less expanded compared to the apex. This makes the ventilation per unit volume rise as the lung expansion is relatively small. 

The alveolar pressure also decreases thus reducing the compression of the vessels and increasing the pulmonary blood flow at the base. An increase in perfusion is more than an increase in ventilation, i.e., denominator increases. Hence, the ratio decreases.

At the apex (against gravity):

Both ventilation and perfusion decrease since the flow is against gravity.

The reason for decreased ventilation is that at the start of inspiration, intrapleural pressure is more negative thus making the intrapulmonary intrapleural pressure difference increase at the apex. The apex is above the level of the heart and capillary pressure at the apex is close to atmospheric pressure thus decreasing the blood flow. But, a decrease in perfusion is higher than a decrease in ventilation. Hence, the ratio increases.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with weakness in his lower limbs. On motor examination, the resident taps on the patellar tendon with a knee hammer and there was a sudden kicking movement of the knee. Which of the following is true about the given reflex?

choices.text: Root value of the reflex is L5 - S2
It is a monosynaptic stretch reflex
Efferent is acted upon γ-motor neurons of the hamstring muscles

questions.solution:
From the given scenario, the resident is performing a knee jerk reflex (patellar reflex) on this patient. 

Knee jerk or patellar reflex is elicited by tapping the patellar tendon resulting in contraction of the quadriceps muscle. It is an example of a deep tendon reflex or myotatic stretch reflex as stretching the muscle causes reflex contraction. 

The reflex arc in the knee jerk reflex consists of only one synapse between afferents and efferents. Hence, it is also an example of a monosynaptic reflex. 

Reflex arc of knee jerk reflex -  

Tapping the tendon causes a stretch of the muscle spindle which is present within the muscle. The muscle spindle is a sensory proprioceptor responsible for identifying the length of the muscle fibers. The Ia afferent sensory fibers in the muscle spindles are activated in response to the stretch. These Ia afferent fibers go to the spinal cord at the dorsal root ganglia and stimulate the alpha-motor neurons. This results in the contraction of the muscle that was initially stretched. The neurotransmitter at the central synapse is glutamate.

The femoral nerve L2-L4 mediates the patellar reflex.

 

Clinical aspect: 

  • Brisk, hyperactive deep tendon reflexes are seen in upper motor neuron lesions affecting the descending spinal tracts like the corticospinal tract. 
  • Hypoactive or absent reflexes are seen in lower motor neuron lesions or the lesions affecting the components of the reflex arc. Absent reflexes can be seen in diabetes, deep sleep, coma, nerve block, spinal anesthesia etc. 
  • The pendular knee jerk, in which tapping the patellar tendon results in to-and-fro movements of the limb is seen in cerebellar lesions. The increased swinging occurs due to hypotonia of both flexors and extensors leading to a lack of restraint on each other.

questions.text: Which of the following has the lowest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation?
questions.solution:
Among the fetal blood vessels mentioned above, the superior vena cava (SVC) has the lowest oxygen concentration. It carries deoxygenated blood from the upper part of the body to the right atrium.

The pO2 of SVC is about 12-14 mmHg whereas the pO2 of the umbilical artery is about 20-25 mm Hg. This is because the SVC carries only deoxygenated blood, whereas the umbilical artery carries a mix of oxygenated blood from the ascending aorta and deoxygenated blood from systemic circulation.

Fetal circulation:

The blood gets oxygenated in the placenta and this passes to the umbilical vein. From the umbilical vein, 50% of the blood enters the hepatic circulation and 50% bypasses the liver to enter the inferior vena cava. Thus, the inferior vena cava, which also carries blood from hepatic veins, kidneys, and from lower extremities, carries a mixture of deoxygenated and oxygenated blood. So, the highest percentage of oxygen in fetal circulation is in the umbilical vein, followed by the inferior vena cava. 

The blood then enters the heart via the right atrium. The right atrium also receives purely deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava. This blood then enters the pulmonary artery. Since fetal lungs are collapsed, most of the blood enters the descending aorta via ductus arteriosus and is then distributed to the body. 

Finally, some of this blood from the aorta and the lower parts of the body is pumped back to the placenta via umbilical arteries. Hence, they contain a mix of both oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. 

The rough estimate of oxygenation of the vessels in the fetal circulation is given below:

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

The total fetal cardiac output at term is approximately 450 mL/kg/min.

questions.text: The following image shows the sequence of propulsion of a bolus in the gut by means of peristalsis. Which of the following substances is responsible for the configuration of the segment of the gut marked as '2'?
questions.solution:
The given configuration of the segment marked by '2' is due to the vasoactive intestinal peptide being responsible for a state of relaxation of this part of the gut. 

The above image shows peristalsis. It is a reflex response that is initiated when the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen. The given segment of relaxation is an anterograde segment that moves from an oral to a caudal direction. 

Stretching of the gut wall releases serotonin and activates the cholinergic neurons present in the myenteric plexus. Cholinergic neurons passing in an anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus. Cholinergic neurons passing in a retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

The following image shows the events as described.

 

Note:

In achalasia cardia, there is a defective release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text:
Match the following hormones to their respective receptor's target of action.
Hormone Target
1. Thyroid hormone A. Receptor tyrosine kinase 
2. Insulin B. Adenylyl cyclase
3. Atrial natriuretic peptide C. Intracellular receptor
4. Norepinephrine D. Guanylyl cyclase
questions.solution:
The correct option is Option 3: 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

1. Thyroid hormones C. Intracellular receptor
2. Insulin A. Receptor tyrosine kinase 
3. Atrial natriuretic peptide D. Guanylyl cyclase
4. Norepinephrine B. Adenylyl cyclase

Thyroid hormones act on intracellular receptors (intracytoplasmic or intranuclear) to induce the transcription of selected mRNAs, thereby promoting protein synthesis. Other hormones with similar action include steroid hormones and retinoic acid.

Insulin activates the tyrosine kinase enzyme on the intracellular (cytoplasmic) portions of transmembrane receptors, thereby phosphorylating the receptor. Other hormones with similar action include EGF, PDGF, M-CSF

Atrial natriuretic peptide increases intracellular cGMP by activating the enzyme guanylyl cyclase. A similar mechanism of action is seen with nitric oxide (NO).

Norepinephrine acts on intracellular adenylyl cyclase enzyme via beta-1 (adenylyl cyclase activation to increase cAMP) and alpha-2 (adenylyl cyclase inhibition to decrease cAMP). It activates phospholipase C and increases the production of DAG, IP3, via alpha-1 receptors.

questions.text: An oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve of a 30-year-old athlete was recorded. If curve 3 represents the dissociation curve during rest, how would the graph shift if he was exercising?
questions.solution:
From the given scenario, during exercise, the oxygen hemoglobin curve shifts considerably towards the right and is denoted by the curve 4.

Curve 3 represents the normal oxygen hemoglobin curve during rest. 

Conditions that cause a right shift (curve 3 to curve 4) in the oxygen hemoglobin curve are: (Conditions with the increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis

Conditions that cause a left shift (curve 3 to curve 2)  in the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve are:

  • Decreased carbon dioxide
  • ↑ pH of the blood
  • ↓ in the temperature of the body

Curve 1 represents the Myoglobin-O2 binding curve. It is a rectangular hyperbola (unlike a sigmoid curve of the oxygen-hemoglobin curve). This is because it only has a single oxygen binding site. It is present in muscles in large amounts and can provide oxygen to muscles even at low blood oxygen levels.

questions.text: The agglutination test of a 2-day-old baby born to an Rh-negative mother is given below. The baby is at the risk of having hemolytic reactions due to the presence of?
questions.solution:
The baby is at the risk of having hemolytic reactions due to the presence of the D antigen. The given agglutination test shows agglutination only with the Rh antiserum. The Rh antigen in the given options is the D antigen.

From the given agglutination test, the blood group of the baby is O-positive, as there is agglutination with the Rh antiserum, but no agglutination with A or B antisera. 

Rh alloimmunization occurs when an Rh-negative mother produces antibodies to Rh antigens due to an Rh-positive fetus. 

In an Rh-positive individual, the presence of the D antigen is specific and carries antigenic properties responsible for hemolytic reactions. 

There are six common types of Rh antigens (C, D, E and c, d, e) each of which is called an Rh factor. The type D antigen is more antigenic than the others. Individuals who have the type D antigen are said to be Rh-positive, whereas those who don't have it are Rh-negative.

ABO blood typing is performed by mixing the individual's red blood cells with antisera that contains the various agglutinins on a slide and observing for the presence of clumping or agglutination.

B BB or OB B Anti-A

The H antigen is present in all four blood groups (A, B, AB, and O). A rare blood group where there is an absence of the H antigen is known as the Bombay blood group. Absence of this H antigen results in absence of A and B antigens. Their plasma contains anti-A, anti-B, and strong anti-H antibodies. Therefore, they do not react with anti-A, anti-B, and anti-AB antiserums, and get recognized as O blood group on cell typing.

However, the O blood group has an H antigen. Thus if a patient with the Bombay blood group is transfused with the O blood group blood, the anti-H antibodies in the Bombay blood group patient react with the H antigen present in the O blood group. This can lead to fatal transfusion reactions. Therefore, patients with the Bombay blood group require the same blood group during transfusion.  

Other less common systems of blood grouping include MNSs, Lutheran, Kell, and Kidd systems of blood grouping.

questions.text: After a meal, the plasma levels of insulin has peaked in a person. Which of the following glucose transporters would facilitate the uptake of glucose by the skeletal muscles mediated by insulin?
questions.solution:
The glucose transporter that would facilitate the uptake of glucose by the skeletal muscles mediated by insulin is GLUT-4.

Normally, a pool of GLUT-4 molecules is maintained within vesicles in the cytoplasm of the insulin-sensitive cells. When the insulin receptors in them are stimulated, the vesicles move rapidly and fuse themselves to the cell membrane and facilitate the transport of glucose molecules into the cells.

This GLUT-4 receptor is also present in cardiac muscle and adispose tissues.

6. Vital capacity 3.5L

Which among the following capacities has been incorrectly calculated by the technician?
questions.solution:
The technician has recorded inspiratory reserve volume, inspiratory capacity, and vital capacity wrongly.

In the above graph, 

Tidal volume (TV) is the amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration or the amount of air that moves out with each expiration during quiet breathing. In this patient it is 0.5L. The normal values are 500-750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) is the air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the tidal volume. In this patient, it is 6-3L = 3L. The normal values are around 2L.

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is the volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration. In this patient it is 2.5-1.5 = 1L. The normal value is around 1L.

Inspiratory capacity (IC) is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level. It can be calculated as TV+IRV which is 0.5L + 3L= 3.5L. The normal value is around 2.5L.

Expiratory capacity (EC) is the maximum amount of air expired after a normal inspiration. It is calculated as TV+ERV, which is 0.5L + 1L = 1.5 L. Normal value is around 1.5L

Vital capacity (VC) refers to the maximum amount of air expired after full inspiration. It is calculated as TV+IRV+ERV. In this patient it is 0.5+ 3+1 =4.5L. The normal value is around 3.5L.

Other important lung values:

The forced vital capacity (FVC), is the largest amount of air that can be expired after a maximal inspiratory effort.

Forced expiratory volume in the first second, FEV1, is the fraction of the vital capacity expired during the first second. 

Respiratory minute volume (RVV) is a measurement of the amount of air that enters the lungs per minute. It is calculated as respiratory rate X tidal volume.

Maximal voluntary respiration (MVV), is the largest volume of gas that can be moved into and out of the lungs in 1 min by voluntary effort.

Total lung capacity is the total volume of the lung. It can be calculated by adding tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume. Normal total lung capacity is around 5L.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman was detected with a positive antibody titer against the thyroid peroxidase enzyme. All of the following steps are catalyzed by this enzyme for the synthesis of thyroid hormones except?
questions.solution:
Iodide trapping (iodide uptake) is not catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase. Oxidation, organification, and coupling are catalyzed by it.  

Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone: 

  • Iodide uptake: The basolateral sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) actively takes up I- (iodide) from the circulation into the follicular cells. The process of concentrating iodide in the cell is known as iodide trapping. Iodide is then transported into the colloid through a pendrin (chloride-iodide) transporter.
  • Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin (Tg), is a large glycoprotein rich in tyrosine residues. It is synthesized by the thyrocytes and secreted into colloid.
  • Iodination of thyroglobulin: This is regulated by the thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme. TPO has three functions: 
    • Oxidation: TPO oxidizes iodine in the presence of H2O2
    • Organification: TPO links tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin with iodine (I2) to form monoiodotyrosine (MIT), diiodotyrosine (DIT)
    • Coupling reactions: TPO combines iodinated tyrosine residues to make MIT + DIT = T3 (triiodothyronine), DIT + DIT = T4 (tetraiodothyronine)
  • Storage: Thyroid hormones are bound to thyroglobulin and stored in the follicular lumen as colloids. The colloid has hormone reserves for 2-3 months
  • Release: Iodinated thyroglobulin is cleaved by lysosomal proteolytic enzymes in the colloid from the thyroid cells. This releases thyroxine and triiodothyronine into the peripheral blood. 
  • Peripheral T3 conversion: T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which is the active form of the hormone.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing an evaluation for shortness of breath. A test to assess the diffusing capacity of the lungs is done. This is measured using one of the following gas components?
questions.solution:
The diffusion capacity of the lungs is measured with carbon monoxide (CO).

The diffusing of CO is diffusion-limited and hence the diffusion capacity for CO called DLCO is measured as an index of diffusing capacity of the lung.

The diffusing capacity of the lung for a given gas is directly proportional to the surface area of the alveolar-capillary membrane and inversely proportional to its thickness.

In this test, a small amount of CO is used to measure the alveolar gas exchange during a 10-second breath-hold. The CO in exhaled breath is then analyzed and the quantity of CO that crosses the alveolar membrane is determined. The normal value of DLco at rest is about 25 mL/min/mm Hg.

DLCO is decreased in patients with:

  • Interstitial lung disease
  • Emphysema (chronic bronchitis usually have normal DLCO)

DLCO is increased in patients with:

  • Obesity
  • Asthma
  • Pulmonary hemorrhage
  • Exercise

questions.text: Levels of a specific hormone secreted from the adrenocortical region, for 24 hours were plotted in a group of 40 people, and the findings are given below. Excessive synthesis of this hormone can lead to all the given features except?
questions.solution:
The adrenocortical hormone likely plotted above is cortisol as the graph shows a diurnal variation with the maximum peak occurring around 8.00 AM. Excessive synthesis of this hormone does not cause enhanced cellular immunity. 

Cortisol suppresses cellular immunity by inhibiting the production of IL-2 and decreasing the proliferation of T-lymphocytes. This action is used for suppressing immunity by administering exogenous glucocorticoids to reduce the rejection reactions during transplantation.  

Cortisol is secreted in a pulsatile fashion and has a diurnal variation in its level. The maximum level occurs in the morning just before awakening (at around 8.00 AM). It gradually declines later and the lowest levels are seen in the evening and midnight, after falling asleep. 

Cortisol is the major glucocorticoid hormone synthesized in the adrenal cortex, mainly in the zona fasciculata layer. Its actions are - 

i) Metabolic effects:

  • On carbohydrates: It stimulates gluconeogenesis, increases glycogen synthesis, and decreases the utilization of glucose in peripheral tissues. Thus, excess stimulation of cortisol causes hyperglycemia. 
  • On fat: Increases lipolysis. 
  • On protein: Exerts a catabolic effect and causes proteolysis
  • Effect on appetite: Increases the appetite and food intake by inducing the synthesis of neuropeptide-Y.

ii) Anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects:

  • Induce the synthesis of lipocortin, an inhibitor of phospholipase A2
  • Inhibit the release of histamine and serotonin 
  • Inhibit the production of IL-2 and T lymphocytes, and depresses cellular immunity

iii) Maintenance of vascular responsiveness to catecholamines:

  • Cortisol up-regulates α1 receptors on arterioles, increasing their sensitivity to the vasoconstrictor effect of norepinephrine, thereby causing hypertension in hypercortisolism. 

iv) Bone formation inhibition by decreasing the type 1 collagen synthesis, intestinal calcium absorption, and osteoblastic activity. 

v) In the central nervous system, cortisol receptors are majorly found in the limbic system. Hence, stimulation of this decreases the rapid eye movement during sleep and increases awake time. Thus, high levels of cortisol are seen in the morning just before awakening.

questions.text: A randomized control study was conducted on a group of 100 people to find out the causes and effects of different hormones that increase the secretion of insulin. All of the following factors increase its secretion except?
questions.solution:
Somatostatin decreases insulin secretion, whereas all others- acetylcholine, gastric inhibitory polypeptide, and arginine stimulate insulin secretion. 

Somatostatin, also known as growth hormone-inhibitory hormone, is secreted from delta cells of the islets of Langerhans. It acts locally from these cells to inhibit insulin and glucagon secretion. It decreases the utilization of the absorbed nutrients by the tissues. The main role of this hormone is to prevent rapid exhaustion of the food, thereby making it available over a longer period of time. 

Insulin is secreted by the pancreatic beta cells in response to increased blood glucose concentration. It promotes liver uptake, storage, and the utilization of glucose from the blood. If blood glucose levels are high, they cause glucose to be rapidly stored in the liver in the form of glycogen. It also promotes the conversion of this excess glucose to fatty acids. When glucose levels fall, insulin secretion is decreased and activation of enzyme phosphorylase split glycogen to release stored glucose into the circulating blood. 

Mechanism of insulin secretion:

Glucose enters beta cells of the pancreas via GLUT-2 receptors. Once inside, it is phosphorylated by glucokinase (rate-limiting step) to glucose-6-phosphate which is oxidized to form adenosine triphosphate (ATP). This ATP causes the closure of ATP-sensitive potassium channels and hence depolarization. This leads to opening voltage-gated calcium channels and Ca2+ influx. This stimulates the fusion of the insulin-containing vesicles with the cell membrane and the secretion of insulin into the extracellular fluid by exocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a monoamine neurotransmitter?
questions.solution:
GABA is not a monoamine neurotransmitter. It is an amino acid.

Biogenic amines are small, charged molecules that are synthesized from amino acids and contain an amino group (R—NH2). Amines known to act as neurotransmitters are dopamine, norepinephrine (noradrenaline), epinephrine (adrenaline), serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine [5-HT]).

Amino acids and their derived amines acting as neurotransmitters:

  • Tryptophan - serotonin
  • Histidine - histamine

questions.text: A student was asked to record ECG by using bipolar limb leads. The below image shows the arrangement of the bipolar electrodes and the potentials recorded across lead I and lead II. What is the potential recorded across lead III?
questions.solution:
According to Einthoven’s law, the potential recorded across lead III is +0.7 mV 

Einthoven’s Law: Einthoven’s law states that if the ECGs are recorded simultaneously with the three limb leads, the sum of the potentials recorded in leads I and III will equal the potential in lead II.

Lead I potential + Lead III potential = Lead II potential

Lead III = Lead II – Lead I = (1.2-0.5) = +0.7 mV

Note: Einthoven's triangle is an imaginary triangle drawn around the area of the heart. It is formed by the arrangement of three bipolar limb leads (the two arms and left leg)

questions.text: Doppler flowmetry of the brain in a 28-year-old patient showed increased cerebral blood flow. Cerebral blood flow is increased in all of the given situations except:
questions.solution:
Cerebral blood flow is increased in all of the above situations except for raised intracranial pressure.

As brain tissue and spinal fluid are essentially incompressible, the volume of blood, spinal fluid, and brain in the cranium at any time must be relatively constant (Monro- Kellie doctrine). Therefore, if the intracranial pressure increases, cerebral vessels get compressed. Hence, an increase in intracranial pressure compromises cerebral blood flow. 

Normal cerebral blood flow is around 50-65mL/100g of brain tissue/min. 

  • Factors that increase cerebral blood flow
    • Increased H+ ion concentration which causes vasodilation of cerebral vessels
    • Increased arterial pCO2 that combines with water to form carbonic acid and release H+ ions
    • Substances that decrease the pH in the blood like lactic acid, pyruvic acid etc 
    • Hypoxia immediately increases blood flow as brain is sensitive to even slightly low levels of oxygen drop
    • Substances released from astrocytes- NO, K+, adenosine, etc 

Related Pearl: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries. 

Areas supplied by various arteries
Anterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure

Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.
Middle Cerebral Artery

Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure

Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.  
Posterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves behind the midbrain

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease has a report showing HCO3- = 23 mEq/L, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, Cl- = 100 mEq/L. Calculate the anion gap in this patient.
questions.solution:
The anion gap in this patient is 22 mEq/L.

Normally, in the serum, the total number of cations is equal to the total number of anions. But, a few of the anions (lactate, phosphate, and sulfate) cannot be measured and this is called an anion gap. It is the difference between measured cations and measured anions and is estimated as:

Plasma anion gap = [Na+ ] − [HCO3− ] - [Cl− ]

Substituting the values = 145−23−100= 22 mEq/L

The normal anion gap ranges between 8-16 mEq/L.

questions.text: The lung compliance of a 40-year-old patient with shortness of breath has been compared to that of a normal person in the pressure-volume curve below. What is the likely diagnosis based on this chart?
questions.solution:
The interpretation of the above pressure-volume curve shows that the patient has increased lung compliance, making the likely diagnosis of pulmonary emphysema. 

Compliance is the tendency for tissue to resume its original position after an applied force has been removed.

After an expiration during quiet breathing, the lungs have a tendency to collapse and the chest wall has a tendency to expand. The interaction between the recoil of the lungs and the recoil of the chest can be measured through a spirometer and a curve of airway pressure plotted against volume is the pressure-volume curve of the total respiratory system (Ptr).

Compliance of the lung and chest wall is measured as the slope of the PTR curve, or, as a change in lung volume per unit change in airway pressure (ΔV/ΔP). 

  • The curve is shifted downwards when compared to normal in case of decreased compliance. Eg. pulmonary edema, and interstitial pulmonary fibrosis due to alveoli being prevented from getting inflated. Decreased compliance is also seen in sarcoidosis.
  • The curve is shifted upwards and to the left in case of increased compliance. Eg. emphysema, normal aging lungs due to decreased elastic recoil of lungs (a tendency of the lungs to become less stretched).

 

Increased compliance seen in emphysema is due to - 

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: The pupillary light reflex is being assessed in a child with suspected cranial nerve palsy. Which two cranial nerves are being tested here?
questions.solution:
The 2nd and 3rd cranial nerves are being tested during the pupillary light reflex. The afferent of pupillary light reflex is the 2nd cranial nerve and the efferent is the 3rd cranial nerve.

When light is shone in one eye, the pupils of both eyes constrict. 

  • Constriction of the pupil of the same eye is called direct reflex.
  • Constriction of the contralateral pupil is called consensual reflex/indirect reflex.  

 

Pupillary light reflex pathway:

  • First-order neurons (sensory) connect each retina with both pretectal nuclei in the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculi. The sensory fibers are carried through the optic nerve. 
  • Second-order neurons (internuncial) connect each pretectal nucleus to bilateral Edinger–Westphal nuclei.
  • Third-order neurons (preganglionic motor) connect the Edinger–Westphal nucleus to the ciliary ganglion. These parasympathetic fibers pass via the oculomotor nerve. 
  • Fourth-order neurons (postganglionic motor) leave the ciliary ganglion and pass into the short ciliary nerves to innervate the sphincter pupillae in both the eyes.

questions.text: A young patient was operated on for a brain tumor. Post-op, it is found that there is an injury to the hypothalamus. All of the following anterior pituitary hormones are likely to be decreased in this patient except:
questions.solution:
Following damage to the hypothalamus, all the hormones secreted by the anterior pituitary will decrease except prolactin. 

The hypothalamus plays an important role in controlling the hormones released from the anterior pituitary. It mainly stimulates the production of all the other anterior pituitary hormones except prolactin. It inhibits prolactin production by releasing prolactin inhibitory hormones. 

Therefore, any injury to the hypothalamus or damage to the hypothalamic-hypophysial portal system, the levels of other anterior pituitary hormones are decreased, while the prolactin levels are increased.

Prolactin is secreted by the lactotropes of the anterior pituitary. Structurally it is similar to human growth hormone and human chorionic somatomammotropin (hCS).

Levels of prolactin are increased during exercise, surgical and psychological stresses, stimulation of the nipple, sleep, pregnancy, thyrotropin-releasing hormone, etc.

The important function of prolactin is to cause milk secretion and prevent ovulation in a lactating mother. It increases the production of casein and lactalbumin. Increased prolactin decreases the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormones, and subsequently decreases the secretion of gonadotropins. 

Clinical correlation - Dopamine released from the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus decreases the secretion of prolactin. Therefore, L dopa which is a precursor of dopamine decreases prolactin secretion, and dopamine antagonists like chlorpromazine and antipsychotics increase the prolactin secretion.

questions.text: A person has consumed a meal rich in protein. Which of the following substances would primarily be secreted that would cause an increase in the secretion of acid in the stomach?
questions.solution:
When a meal rich in protein has been consumed, the increase in the secretion of acid in the stomach is likely due to gastrin. 

The peptides and amino acids have a special stimulatory effect on the gastric cells located in the pyloric antrum, causing the secretion of gastrin. This further increases the hydrochloric acid secretion. 

Stimuli that increase acid and gastrin secretion:

  • Distension of stomach
  • Peptides
  • Calcium
  • Increased vagal discharge

Stimuli that decrease acid and gastrin secretion:

  • Gastric acid
  • Secretin family - secretin, glucagon, VIP, GIP
  • Somatostatin
  • Calcitonin

Related Pearl: Stimuli for gastric secretion

Stimuli

Mechanism

Applied aspects

Vagal stimulation

Direct pathway

Vagus nerve innervates parietal cells and stimulates H+ secretion directly.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is Ach, the receptor on the parietal cells is muscarinic (M3)

The second messengers for CCK are IP3 and increased intracellular [Ca2+].

Atropine, a cholinergic muscarinic antagonist, inhibits H+ secretion by blocking the direct pathway, which uses ACh as a neurotransmitter. However, it does not block H+ secretion completely because it does not inhibit the indirect pathway, which uses GRP as a neurotransmitter

Indirect pathway

Vagus nerve innervates G cells and stimulates gastrin secretion, which then stimulates H+ secretion.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is GRP (not ACh).

Vagotomy eliminates both direct and indirect pathways.

Gastrin

Released in response to eating a meal (small peptides, distension of the stomach, vagal stimulation).

Stimulates H+ secretion by interacting with the cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptor on the parietal cells.

The second messenger for gastrin on the parietal cell is IP3/Ca2+.

  

Histamine

Released from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the gastric mucosa and diffuses to the nearby parietal cells.

Stimulates H+ secretion by activating H2 receptors on the parietal cell membrane.

The H2 receptor is coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gs protein.

The second messenger for histamine is cAMP.

H2 receptor–blocking drugs, such as cimetidine, inhibit H+ secretion by blocking the stimulatory effect of histamine.

questions.text: A young male patient was diagnosed with intracranial hemorrhage. He was started on hypertonic saline. He was in a road traffic accident and CT confirmed the diagnosis. Which of the following images best depicts the changes in the fluid volumes after administration of the given saline?
questions.solution:
After the administration of hypertonic saline, the changes in the fluid volume occur as depicted in image 4.

The clinical features depict raised intracranial pressure due to intracranial hemorrhage. Patients are started on osmotic diuretics like mannitol or hypertonic saline to prevent cerebral swelling. Administration of the osmotic agents increases the osmolarity of the plasma. The cerebral tissues have lower osmolarity compared to the plasma. Therefore, this leads to the flow of excess water from cerebral tissues to the blood via osmosis.

Whenever hypertonic saline is added to the extracellular fluid (ECF), the extracellular osmolarity increases. It causes osmosis of water out of the cells into the extracellular compartment. Almost all the added sodium chloride remains in the extracellular compartment and fluid diffuses into the extracellular space to achieve osmotic equilibrium. The net effect is that the volume of ECF increases, the volumes of intracellular fluid (ICF) decreases, and the osmolarity of both the compartments increase. 

Whenever isotonic saline is added to the extracellular fluid, the osmolarity of fluids does not change. The main effect is that it increases the ECF volume

Whenever hypotonic saline is added to ECF, the osmolarity of ECF decreases. This leads to the movement of water from the ECF to the ICF until both attain the same osmolarity. Both the intracellular and extracellular volumes are increased by the addition of hypotonic fluid, but the intracellular volume increases to a greater extent. Osmolarity decreases in both the compartments.

  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: Which heart sound occurs immediately after the pressure waveform indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
The heart sound occurring just after the pressure waveform marked by the arrow is S1. The waveform marked in the image is 'a wave' and it corresponds to atrial contraction.

S1 (first heart sound) is heard in the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle where ventricles contract against closed mitral valves. This occurs after atrial systole, corresponding to an 'a' wave in the jugular venous pressure. Thus, S1 can be heard just after the 'a' wave. 

Jugular venous pressure measured in the internal jugular vein (IJV) is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. IJV is preferred because it is not valved and is in direct line with the superior vena cava and right atrium. 

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.

The Wiggers diagram given below correlates JVP with other aspects of the cardiac cycle. 

Other options - 

Option A: S4 is heard in the phase of atrial systole where atria contract in the late stage of ventricular filling. This occurs just before S1 and 'a' wave in the JVP. 

Option B: S3 is heard in the passive ventricular filling phase where mitral valves are open. It is seen after the 'v' wave peak in the JVP. 

Option C: S2 is heard due to the closure of aortic and pulmonary valves in the isovolumetric relaxation phase after ventricular systole. It can be heard just before the 'v' wave corresponding to the JVP waveform.
